### **Parable of the Razor and the Sword**  

There were two craftsmen, both called to build houses for the King.  

The first carried with him a **Razor**. His blade was sharp and single-edged. Whenever he found a crooked beam or a knot in the wood, he shaved it away. â€œThe house must be simple, plain, and clean,â€ he said. â€œToo many parts only confuse the eye.â€ And so his house stood straight and narrow, easy to look upon, but thin as paper in the wind.

But I did not look at him as a sinner; I looked at him as a man caught between systems.  

I handed him forty pieces, not of silver, but of our modern wage, and he gave me in return what he called â€œa halfâ€ â€” a portion weighed, cut, divided according to the measures of men. Alongside it, I took two trees, for even in the dark places the image of Eden appeared again. I thought of the tree of life and the tree of knowledge, standing on either side of the river in Revelation, and here I was, with two small trees in my hands, walking out of the shadows of trade.  

Before I left, I spoke to him plainly:  
> â€œThe only fault I find in you is this â€” not that you sell, for all markets sell, both those in the open and those in the dark. My fault with you is that you sell without truth. You hand men a measure, but not the meaning. You give them a substance, but not the word that should accompany it. You have supplied me not with sin, but with work. For in truth, you have given me many souls to labor with, men and women whom the world has condemned. Yet they are not condemned by God. Only by tariffs.â€

They twist the scales and decree: *this is clean, this is unclean; this is lawful, this is unlawful*. But Heaven does not weigh with such tariffs. Heaven has no customs office, no toll booths, no tax upon grace.

I thanked him before I left, not because his trade was pure, but because it showed me the shadow of the greater market: the market of menâ€™s souls, where all are bartered under law, weighed under tariffs, and condemned by systems that never loved them. For I knew then that this too was part of the testimony â€” that truth walks even through the black markets, even in the places condemned, because the Lord Himself was accused of eating with tax collectors and sinners.  

And as I walked out, I thought: the **tariffs of SIN** are the false coverings of the law of men, but the covering of Christ is free. His burden is light. His yoke has no tariff.
